conclusion: The problem asks whether the difference in displacement between two objects, A and B, is necessarily continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t1.
The displacement of an object can be found by calculating the area under its v-t graph.
If the v-t graph is above the t-axis, the area represents positive displacement, and if the v-t graph is below the t-axis, the area represents negative displacement.
The given v-t graph shows two curves, one for object A and one for object B, both starting at the origin and ending at t1.
The curve for object A is always above the curve for object B until t1.
The area under the curve for object A represents the total displacement of A, and the area under the curve for object B represents the total displacement of B.
The difference in displacement between the two objects at any time t is given by the difference in the areas under their v-t graphs up to that time t.
Since the curve for A is always above the curve for B until t1, the area under the curve for A is always greater than the area under the curve for B up to t1.
The difference in displacement between the two objects is continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t1.
The final answer is: Yes, the difference in displacement between the two objects is necessarily continuously increasing.
